content:
I've made a few sanity (trailing whitespace at the end of validator 3), clarity (I/O format) and esthetic (consistent typography) updates.

I've solved using both memo'd simulation and the proper algorithm, so it's good to go for me, I'm upvoting now and approving as soon as I finish typing this comment.
(As noted elsewhere, if what you were after was proper algorithm only, the test cases should be made harder)

When I was younger and played that, the variant was the "take-1-to-3 objects" non-misère one, so I thought my algorithm wouldn't apply there and implemented simulation. Then I discovered how the proper alg was both easier and harder than mine and implemented that too. Thanks for the opportunity to learn something new!

(I've added the heap ordering constraint, as I discovered it was the case in the validators, and it does make memoizing marginally easier, so why not use it.)

with current constraints it is still bruteforce-able. while my attempt with recursion and memoization timed out on the last two testcases, it was doing some pretty suboptimal array operations to get memoization key and to get a copied and modified array to pass to the resursive call. 
my second approach of filling the array from the low values up instead of recursion was able to fill the full 50x50x50 cases in under half a second. and you don't even have a testcase for 50x50x50 really.
in other languages, especially ones that can use any structure as key in a map or that have efficient immutable list implementations or are especially good with memoization, etc, even the recursive solution will probably fit within the time limit

if your intent is to have people find the actual strategy a human would use for the game instead of brute-force, you should increase the limits on M substantially.

a version with more heaps could also be interesting for those like satine that know the algo for 3 :p

I think there should be one more testcase, something like 2 3 7
Is there any way to add testcases, other than remaking the puzzle from scratch?
I know this algorithm! It’s quite an interesting one (but very hard to find on own will) ^^
You can edit the puzzle and add one test case ^^ (but I already see 2 3 7 in your test cases)

let this one be solvable by memo'd simulation
You can make a differnt puzzle with harder testcases if you wish so
That's becaues I have replaced an existing testcase. I can't find an option to add a testcase to submitted puzzle, only to remove...
Mhh, I have a button "ADD A TEST CASE" on my own puzzle ; I guess you reached the limit with 8 tests then ^^
I have updated the puzzle to allow several positions in one testcase. I wonder if people are into this stuff however. I personally was quite fascinated by misere nim back in the days.
When I was quite young, I discovered this algorithm on a program in Pascal, and was awed as well. Nowadays, it can be easily found in Wikipedia (demonstration included) ^^
Well, I expected something like that. That puzzle, "Minimum number of swaps", gave me an idea, that not every puzzle should be made hard.
